She doesn't know that the handbag had actually been taken by her husband Tony. He is a former tennis pro but now he is living on his wife's wealth and is concerned that she may leave him he doesn't want her, just her money, so he plots what he thinks is the perfect murder. Having seen a rather disreputable character he knew when he was up at Cambridge he uses a combination of blackmail and payment to get the man to kill Margot. Things don't go according to plan; Margot fights back and her attacker ends up dead. Now Tony has another plan while acting as though he is trying to help her he works to ensure she is hanged for murder!Given that this film is based on a play it isn't too surprising that it has a very theatrical feel; largely because almost all of the action takes place in the Wendice's flat. This isn't a problem though as the story is solid. Tony's scheme is just about plausible and the way he reacts after it fails almost makes him feel more villainous and the scene where the attempted murder takes place is intense as the attacker tries to strangle Margot with a stocking and she fights back with a pair of scissors. Ray Milland does a fine job as Tony, keeping him outwardly respectable rather than a pantomime villain. Grace Kelly is also solid as Margot. The rest of the cast are pretty good too. Inevitably some of the attitudes displayed are rather dated; most notably when a policeman warns a junior colleague to be careful how he carries Margot's handbag or he could be arrested himself no doubt this was meant to give viewers a chuckle but these days seems rather shocking. Overall I wouldn't say that this was a classic Hitchcock film but it is still well worth watching.

reviews.review_title: Poor to average Hitch, but essential viewing for the nightgown scene!
reviews.content: Pretty poor Hitch. Too long dialogue scenes, not enough action - its like a static stage play. Very unmemorable "husband-wife betrayal" plot material.It has one scene, however, which makes it essential viewing for Hitchcock and Grace Kelly fans alike - for it is one of both their greatest moments, and the scene that made her famous. It is the scene where Grace Kelly answers the telephone in that diaphanous nightgown, and a man puts a rope around her neck. A fantastic scene, a memorable moment - the only really great thing in this movie.But its great enough to recommend it to you.5/10. But essential viewing for the nightgown scene.

reviews.review_title: A gem by the legendary Alfred Hitchcock
reviews.content: Dial M for Murder is a crime mystery thriller directed by one of the greatest mystery director Late Alfred Hitchcock and stars Late Ray Milland, Late Grace Kelly, Late Robert Cummings, Late John Williams and Late Anthony Dawson.I am no capacity to review this classic made by the Great Late Hitchcock but the only thing I have to say is that the movie is so mesmerizing that it will keep you glued throughout the end.The plot is nice and screenplay is engaging with great acting and a superb climax.One of the best mystery thriller and a must watch for everyone.

reviews.review_title: One of the best Hitchcock thrillers
reviews.content:
I've always loved this movie even with all it's flaws and plot holes. Ray Milland steals it playing a cold calculated murderer, but why he would kill someone as gorgeous as Grace Kelly for money is beyond me.
OK she is supposed to be having an affair with the dull Character played by one dimensional Robert Cummings but really?The plot is indeed full of holes but it still grips and I always forget the ending until the very end.
A good play that shouldn't translate to the big screen but only Hitchcock could carry this off and he does,Few movies can work with mainly one room scenes but this one does, although not as well as the brilliant 12 Angry men..

An ex-tennis pro carries out a plot to murder his wife. When things go wrong, he improvises a brilliant plan B.I don't remember a whole lot about this film, as I've only seen it once and it was a few years ago. I do recall it being a pretty good movie though- it's all shot on pretty much one set, so it starts to fell perhaps a little dull and claustrophobic after a while, but maybe this was the intended effect. It also marks the first time Grace Kelly starred in a Hitchcock film, and she definitely does a good job here. It's a fine film, with at least a couple of stand-out sequences, but it does become a little tedious in its final act. 7/10

From what I've read, Hitchcock took the job of directing Dial M for Murder as little more than the last contracted film he had to do to complete his relationship with Warner Brothers. It also lacks certain marks of Hitchcock's, like how he was free with adapting material to change things such as who the killer was, keeping the original stage play pretty much wholly intact. And yet, despite Hitchcock's apparent disengagement with the material, he still managed to craft a highly entertaining and twisting mystery.Tony Wendice is a former tennis pro turned athletic equipment salesman who married the wealthy Margot. He's known for a year that she carried on an affair with the American mystery writer Mark. When Mark comes back to London for a visit, he sends both of them off on the town for the evening and invites Swann, an old schoolmate of Tony's, over. Tony knows of Swann's troubles with the law that he's always just a step ahead on, and he, in a steady drip of storytelling and implied threats, convinces Swann to murder Margot for a thousand pounds.The first thirty minutes of the film remind me of Gambit, the Shirley MacLaine and Michael Caine film from more than a decade later, that spends its first long stretch outlining an illegal activity in rather exacting detail only to watch the scheme (a murder and a con) begin to fall apart almost instantly as the action begins to move. Tony can't get his wife's key as easily as he expected, so he has to have an extended back and forth in order to take it from her handbag without her noticing. He can't place the key outside the apartment where he expected because he and Mark, going out for a stag party as his alibi, leave the apartment in the wrong order. But what's most interesting is how the plotted murder can end up going so wrong and Tony had covered his tracks so well that he can easily lean into another lie that implicates Margot in, not self-defense, but as a calculated murder to silence a man blackmailing her over a letter Mark had written to her (that Tony had stolen, gotten one of Swann's fingerprints on, and placed in the dead man's pocket before the police arrived).The movie promises us one series of actions and then proceeds to completely undermine it by the halfway point, giving us well beyond the promised and delving into the unknown with intelligence. There are details that get dropped (like Tony switching out Swann's scarf for Margot's stocking) that feel inexplicable at the time but get nicely paid off later.One of the things that helps the movie feel so entertaining is the performances. From Ray Milland as Tony to Grace Kelly as Margot and, especially, John Williams as Chief Inspector Hubbard, the actors embody their roles really well, letting the presence and ability to hand dialogue carry us through the actions. Milland's alternatively slimy and sincere performance makes Tony's moves between scheming and supporting of his wife convincing. Kelly's dazed state in the later parts of the film sell well, and Williams is just simply entertaining as the police officer who seems so far behind Tony and then suddenly so far ahead.It's a highly entertaining mystery that moves through its twists deftly and with charm. It's not Hitchcock's best, but, if he was as disengaged as the stories say, then it's probably his best work when he didn't care.

reviews.review_title: Dial M for Master of Suspense
reviews.content: An elaborately written plot and executed perfectly. There is no doubt Alfred Hitchcock is the master of suspense and storytelling. He was and will remain to be the best in his genre. The plot was also backed by some powerful performances by the main actors.The plot keeps you guessing towards the end and at first you might feel sympathy for the either of the characters but those feelings might switch over as the movie progresses. He has a way of making you root for a character despite them being good or bad,Alfred made cameos long before Stan Lee took it on and if you didn't notice him, look closer when they pull up the photograph.

reviews.review_title: Like a Detective Novel on Film
reviews.content: Retired professional tennis player Tony Wendice (Ray Milland) plots against his wife Margot (Grace Kelly). Tony ended his tennis career after Margot complained about his schedule, and a year ago she began an affair, which he secretly discovered, with American crime-fiction writer Mark Halliday (Cummings). For several months, Tony has been investigating C.J. Swann (Dawson), a disreputable fellow Cambridge alumnus who lives in London, in order to blackmail him into murdering Margot.Like the earlier "Strangers on a Train", this film involves a tennis star's dislike of his cheating wife. Either Hitchcock has a weird love of tennis, or tennis players in the 1950s had really bad luck in picking wives.What makes this story really great is how the original idea backfires! A few times, the plot goes in a direction that the lead does not expect, but he is able to think quickly and modify his story for the police in away that keeps him looking innocent and his goals within reach. It's pure brilliance.But best of all is how this film works through like a detective novel, relying on logic more than physical evidence. The mystery writer, without blood or fingerprints is able to deduce a great deal of what happened simply by running thought experiments. How plausible this is, I don't know... but in this film, it works! I personally prefer "Strangers on a Train" or "Rope", but "Dial M" is by no means a bad Hitchcock film. I would urge anyone who has enjoyed Hitchcock in the past to give this one a fair shake.
My most favourite film of all time. A cinematic masterpiece. This is how real cinema is. A classic and timeless art. Mysterious till the end. Extraordinary acting by Grace Kelly. She's beautiful.

Dial M For Murder is quite a good triller from Alfred Hitchcock although tends to be a little slow moving in parts, especially the first half-hour or so.Due to his wife having an affair, Tony Wendice arranges with a former college friend to have her murdered. Things don't go quite to plan though and she ends up killing him in self defence when she stabs him in the back with a pair of scissors. Despite this, she is arrested and sentenced to death. She now has to plead her innocence...One of the low points of the movie is the first half-hour which features just Wendice and his friend plotting the murder his wife and it's shot in just the one room as well. A little too long is this bit.The excellent cast includes Ray Milland, Grace Kelly, Robert Cummings, John Williams, Anthony Dawson and Patrick Allen.Apart from that slow moving half-hour at the beginning, this is an excellent movie.Rating: 3 stars out of 5.

reviews.review_title: Polished screen version of Broadway play...
reviews.content: RAY MILLAND, as a man who devises a plan to have a college associate kill his wife (GRACE KELLY) for her inheritance--and the fact that she's had an affair--is a pleasure to watch in a role that seems almost tailor-made for his emoting. He is just as effective as Maurice Evans was on the stage.Alfred Hitchcock has taken Frederick Knott's play (from a screenplay written by Knotts himself), and carefully built the suspense to the point where a clever mastermind is exposed. The business with the key is extremely effective and the lynch pin that destroys the husband's alibi.GRACE KELLY is smooth but rather bland as the wife (a role offered first to Olivia de Havilland whose salary demands were too high), and ROBERT CUMMINGS has a rather conventional supporting role as the man she really loves. But it's ANTHONY DAWSON as the college chum who agrees to murder Kelly and JOHN WILLIAMS as the fastidious detective who solves the case, that really remain in the memory.Among the more interesting Hitchcock films of this period, it's the sort of detective yarn any mystery fan would enjoy.

reviews.review_title: "Do you really believe in the perfect murder?"
reviews.content: 1954 was an excellent year for fans of the Master of Suspense, Alfred Hitchcock. Not only did he release 'Rear Window'  widely considered his best film  but also 'Dial M for Murder,' his lesser-revered, but certainly not inferior suspenseful murder film. The first of Hitchcock's three collaborations with the beautiful Grace Kelly (along with 'Rear Window' and 'To Catch a Thief'), it was arguably 'Dial M for Murder' that cemented Kelly's reputation as a genuine acting talent, assuring her enduring legacy despite a painfully short-lived film career. The film was adapted very closely by Frederick Knott from his own stage play of the same name, which had previously premiered as a BBC television play two years earlier.'Dial M for Murder' bears certain resemblances to Hitchcock's 1948 film, 'Rope,' in that both are based on stage plays (the latter adapted from a play by Patrick Hamilton), both take place largely in the one setting, and both plots entail characters attempting to get away with "the perfect murder." The setting for 'Dial M for Murder' is an upper-class flat at 61A Charrington Gardens, Maida Vale, London. Most of the film's plot unfolds within these walls, though there is also a single scene set in a restaurant, and a very brief, highly-stylised courtroom montage. Staying true to its stage roots, the film relies heavily on character conversation to advance its plot, a style that could potentially become tedious in less experienced hands. However, the mastery of Hitchcock, coupled with the quality of the acting performances, successfully infuses the film with an ever-present atmosphere of intrigue and suspense.When famous former tennis star Tony Wendice (Ray Milland) discovers that his beautiful and wealthy wife Margot (Grace Kelly) has been cheating on him with American crime writer Mark Halliday (Robert Cummings), he begins to plot the perfect revenge. Enlisting  via blackmail  the services of an ex-college acquaintance (Anthony Dawson), Tony plans to orchestrate the perfect murder of his unfaithful wife without implicating himself. However, as Mark points out to him, the "perfect murder" might not be quite as achievable as it seems: "because, in stories, things usually turn out the way the author wants them to; and in real life, they don't... always."Just like in many of his films, Hitchcock heightens the suspense by subversively enlisting our sympathies for the villain. Nobody in their right minds would wish for the lovely Grace Kelly to be murdered, but somehow we are manipulated into almost hoping that Tony's plan is a success, and we revel in his sly brilliance as he recovers from his initial failure to implement an equally-devious Plan B. By doing this, Hitchcock makes the audience feel as though they are, themselves, a part of the crime, and as though their own fates hinge on the outcome of Chief Insp. Hubbard's (John Williams) investigation. Nonetheless, it is inevitable that the villain be brought to justice, and Tony's inability to accurately predict human behaviour becomes the single, gaping flaw in his flawless plans.To counteract the potential tedium of a film set almost entirely in the one room, Hitchcock makes clever use of colours and camera angles. To trace the downward spiral of an innocent woman who became the focus of sinister deeds, Hitchcock arranged for Grace Kelly to be dressed in bright colours at the start of the film and made them progressively darker as time goes on. A viewer would also, no doubt, have noticed the prevalence of low-angle shots with household objects sometimes, such as lamps, standing between the cast members and the camera. This was done to exploit the 3D-format in which the film was originally shot, though, by the time of the film's release, interest in this gimmick had substantially waned, and only a handful of cinemas showed the film in this way. Nonetheless, even without the 3D, this style of cinematography places the viewer in a unique position, as though they are hidden within the room and secretly observing the characters' most intimate moments.Whilst 'Dial M for Murder' managed to keep my attention throughout its running time, the first half of the film was noticeably more suspenseful than the subsequent half. This "drop-off" might well have been because, in the film's final act, the audience's perspective parts from that of the villain and meets up with the shrewd Englishman detective, Hubbard. From this moment forth, the outcome of the investigation was never really in any doubt, and Tony was bound to be arrested and tried for attempted murder. Every moment up to this point, however, was completely unpredictable, and one hundred percent genuine Alfred Hitchcock suspense.

reviews.review_title: Not my favorite Hitchcock, but still worth watching.
reviews.content: This is a great suspenseful murder mystery brought to you by some great acting and Hitchcock.The overall story involves an unfaithful wife and a has-been tennis pro who plots her death...it is a very well planned out murder, and he almost gets away with it...except a few things don't go as planned.The best line is the lead inspector's crack about amateur detectives! Especially in light of him being very proud of himself for cracking the case.The ultimate way that they catch the culprit is very clever...but I still prefer the similarly themed Barbara Stanwyck film "Sorry Wrong Number".The acting by Ray Milland, Robert Cummings and John Williams is great...really making this a must see. The conclusion is the best part of the plot...so hang in there until the end.Highly recommend this to Hitchcock fans and anyone who likes a good "gotcha!".

reviews.review_title: One of the Most Enjoyable Crime Mysteries
reviews.content: Another terrific example of its genre from the master of suspense, Alfred Hitchcock's Dial M for Murder tells the story of a former tennis player who discovers his wife having an extra-marital affair, devises a foolproof plan to murder her & blackmails one of his acquaintances into carrying out the act. But when things go wrong, he's left with no choice but to improvise.Expertly directed from start to finish, Dial M for Murder remains one of Hitchcock's most enjoyable & entertaining flicks that features a very tightly structured plot & is fine tuned by its cut-throat editing to engage the audience in solving an investigation for which the director provides ample clues to its viewers, but not more than what's available to the characters in the film.With a plot full of twist, turns & confessions, superb performances from Ray Milland, Grace Kelly & Robert Cummings, and exhibiting admirable craftsmanship in every filmmaking department, including cinematography & music, Dial M for Murder is another home run from the master storyteller who made a career out of crafting only intensely entertaining quality motion pictures. Strongly recommended.

reviews.review_title: "Once he opens that door, we shall know everything."
reviews.content: This feature was dismissed by critics and the director himself. Hitchcock had been forced into filming it to complete his contract with Warner Brothers before moving to Paramount, and has stated he could have phoned in direction on the project and the finished product would have been very much the same.Nevertheless, this Hitchcock suspense still deserves plaudits for its intricate plot, and above all, a masterful performance from Ray Milland as the dispassionate architect of a plan to murder his unfaithful wife. It is to our benefit that the studios refused Cary Grant's wishes to perform the role, convinced that the movie-going public would not accept him in the role of a calculating, cold-blooded, murderer. Milland's portrayal of this debonair and unflappable cuckolded former star of the tennis circuit, Tony Wendice, as he engineers both his initial scheme to have his wife murdered, and the subsequent attempt to cover up his involvement in the foiled attempt, should have merited an Academy Award nomination. Other notable performances are provided by Anthony Dawson and John Williams, both of whom reprise their roles from the original theatrical production. Williams would present the most notable cinematic role of his career in this as Chief Inspector Hubbard. This tall, urbane English actor had been a regular on the Broadway stage since the 1920s, and had secured a 'Tony' award for this very same role the previous year. Williams is majestic as the archetypal British detective, who so deftly orchestrates the villain's downfall.For his part, Dawson shares screen time with Milland for this movie's tense, unforgettable, exposition of the latter's plan to blackmail the former into murdering his cheating wife. Part of this extended sequence sees Hitchcock employ an overhead scene where the audience can enjoy a different perspective on the stage on which the planned murder is to take place. This technique would later be more gainfully employed in the staircase murder scene in Hitchcock's masterpiece, 'Psycho'. This sequence also contains a variation on the theme of the director's cameo appearances as Hitchcock is seated at the social gathering in the photograph used to establish Dawson's character's true identity.Hitchcock had turned to adapting this play after a project he was developing entitled 'The Bramble Bush', in which a man who has stolen a passport discovers he has taken in the identity of a murderer, fell through. There are flourishes of Hitchcock at his best, most notably in bringing such tension to a plot largely built on dialogue, and principally set within the four walls of one flat in Maida Vale. Specific scenes which convey his artistry include that of the shadowed pair of lovers on the door to the flat abruptly ending their embrace as the husband is about to enter, and the use of lighting and coloured backdrops behind a static close-up of Grace Kelly to sketch the courtroom setting. Most memorable of all, especially given the fact that this film was shot for a 3D format, is that of the frantic heroine's fight for survival as she reaches out towards the audience to grab the scissors with which she will ultimately fend off her attacker. So important to the director was it that this scene would have the same powerful effect on audiences as he had envisioned it would, that he lost twenty pounds from anxiety at the effort expended to achieve this.Such attention to detail is captured by one of the great director's most famous quotes. In seeking perfection Hitchcock mused: 'Scissors that don't gleam are like asparagus without bearnaise sauce'. In order to capture the moment the scissors impale the attacker's body as he falls upon them, Hitchcock had a pit dug and perched a camera on its edge to film at floor-level.With his studios in the financial doldrums, facing the advent of popular television, Jack Warner had invested heavily in 3D technology which had temporarily caught the imagination of the industry over the previous year to this feature's production. As Hitchcock would muse, this technology was a 'Nine-day wonder' and he had arrived on the ninth day. Indeed, after the film was premiered in the Randolph Theatre in Philadelphia, Grace Kelly's hometown, in its 3D format, by the second evening the performances reverted to 2D after the Theatre's management complained of poor audience feedback and low turnout. One uncharacteristic imperfection to this Hitchcock vehicle which is a vestige of the great director's attempts to harness 3D technology is the giant, and obviously fake finger and telephone, used for Wendice's fateful call from the club to his apparent defenceless wife.The original theatre screenplay by Frederick Knott loses none of its atmosphere from Hitchcock's treatment and is given greater punch by wonderful musical accompaniment. Interestingly, Knott only produced three theatrical plays in his professional career, but they proved so successful that he was able to live off their income. Moreover, the choice of tennis star for the principal protagonist in this work is of no surprise given the fact that the playwright was a gifted player himself whose participation at Wimbledon was prevented by the advent of the Second World War.This was the third and last collaboration between Hitchcock and composer Dimitri Tiomkin in nearly as many years. The latter provides a refrain with a tempo to match the mounting tension for both the phone call to initiate the attempted murder - wrapped around the clicking of the telephone exchange - and Milland's desperate attempts to inculcate his wife as having committed murder in response to attempted blackmail. Despite many voiced concerns over the complexity of the 'latch key' sequence, upon which the unveiling of Milland's plot hinges, for this reveiwer, it holds true tension. Other criticism of this feature centres on Hitchcock's having not 'ventilated' the screenplay by confining the screenplay to within the apartment walls. A master of exploiting confined spaces, such as in 'Lifeboat' and 'Rope', for this reviewer Hitchcock uses this limited space to accentuate the tension, of the developing plot. As Hitchcock commented to Truffaut, opening up a play for cinema audiences 'overlooks the fact that the basic quality of any play is precisely its confinement'.The only true weakness of the film is the casting of Grace Kelly and Robert Cummings as the unfaithful wife and her lover, both of whom fail to engage the audience, so much so, that one almost wishes Milland's character succeed in his despicable plot. In her cinematic debut, Kelly is undeniably beautiful, but comes across as characterless. Ironically, Kelly's character declares at one point: 'What's wrong with me? Shouldn't I be emotional?' As for Cummings, he would never attain a cinematic presence, and would prove more successful on the small screen. One only wonders how much the film would have achieved greater renown had Hitchcock been able to cast his first choice of Deborah Kerr. It is astonishing that to the omission of those cast members who performed so ably on screen, it would be Kelly alone who received a nomination at the BAFTAs. Her most positive contribution to the production was in terms of a costume suggestion. Though Hitchcock had arranged for Kelly to wear an expensive robe for the scene where she is surprised by her assailant, the actress rejected it, stating that no woman would bother to be so attired to answer a phone call when alone in her flat. Thus, this scene was shot with her simply wearing a shift, probably making it both more shocking and titillating to audiences of the time.Offscreen, Kelly's record of dalliances with her older co-stars continued during this feature, but the romance which blossomed between her and Milland almost wrecked her career. Talk of Milland's plans to divorce his wife and marry Kelly soon ended when he was thrown out of the marital home and realised what he was about to lose financially.As for the movie, the director himself in conversation with Francois Truffaut would disregard the film as evidence of him 'coasting' ahead of his move from Warner Brothers to Paramount. He similarly stated to Peter Bogdanovich, when the latter asked why he had directed this adaptation of Knott's play, that: 'When the batteries are running dry, take a hit play and shoot it.' This dismissive attitude is further evidenced by observations made by Grace Kelly that the great director was working on 'Rear Window' even while this production was underway. Whatever his level of motivation was, with this movie he proves himself a master once more at utilising a claustrophobic setting to its best effect.
A classical classic that classically delivers on the well-known Hitchcock tension. This film will without a doubt get a second viewing from me in the not too distant future.

An extraordinary movie. Perfectly portraying the classic elements of the "closed room" mysteries. The actors were spectacular and, ask always AH work is sublime.It had been a while since I last watched it and saw it yesterday and was far more impressed than before.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the avg rating
reviews.content: I was rooting for the guy who was caught red handed in the end.He had two people, his wife and her lover trying to kill his way of life, albeit in a friendly and 'smiley' manner, and he was supposed to just take it.It's the same as if someone tell you he/she hates you and then shoots you, and on the other hand someone else who smiles tells you they love you and then shoots you. No difference, you still get shot.Hitchcock by portraying the woman and her lover as victims was almost able to convince all that the ending was 'righteous'.

Dial M for Murder is one of the best and most intelligent films. Easily one of Hitchcock's finest. This film contains a first class murder story and some stellar performances from a great cast. Hitchcock was at the height of his powers when he made such a great film. It intrigues and stimulates the mind. I couldn't help but compare it to the lack of mysteries and thoughtful films we have today. They don't make films like this anymore. There is no CGI or big effects here. It is a simple setting and most action takes place in a small apartment yet the content and suspense is first class. Highly recommended. 8.5/10

reviews.review_title: The story is so simple, yet so complex - pure genius.
reviews.content: I loved this film so much. The storyline was amazing, all the dialogues were interesting. The whole movie is based on conversations and it works so well, because the story is very complex. There are so many small details put into the story I cannot admire it enough. If you loved 12 Angry Men, you'll love this.

reviews.review_title: A blithe, articulate play about how to kill your beautiful wife
reviews.content: Dial M for MurderAlmost a parlor piece, something like Rope in that sense, and yet more taughtly written and directed, a play of wits, a game for the viewer to follow and anticipate. It is based on a play and, to its benefit, it feels like one. The dialog takes first row, and is crisp and intelligent. The original 3-D intended for the sets (and the sense of claustrophobia, apparently) is lost on most of us, of course, to the point that the color and lighting seem too high-key and pasty instead of rich and dramatic, but you can write it off as a period effect, just before Cinemascope and other wide screen efforts went mainstream.It's surprising how little pyrotechnics you need (and no blood) to make a suspense movie have real suspense. Not the kind where your hair stands up, but your brain snaps on to figure out what's going on, what's likely next, what would you do. By keeping the setting consistent for most of the movie (in Ray Milland's character, the antagonist's, apartment), Hitchcock also avoids any of the false back-projection he seems to be happy with in other, generally better films of his, like Vertigo or North by Northwest, which are both from roughly this period. In all a brilliant piece of writing and elegant, restrained film-making. The acting, too, is worth noting, Milland being utterly convincing, and the inspector, if a bit of a caricature, is also believable. Grace Kelly is always a bit too wooden for her sculptural prettiness for me (I've never understood her iconic appeal at all), but she plays a witless victim well, the kind of dull-headed blonde that Hitchcock favored, to the ill of all smart blondes and women in general. Woe to sensibility!And so we have a brilliant bit of British film-making, made in America (at the Warner studio lots). The original play, and TV teleplay, were both British, the emphasis on words over action is certainly an English cliché in the movie world (and not always a bad thing), and the setting is of course London, with the cliché Scotland Yard types at hand. All of this is quaintly appealing, and keeps an airy feel even as the main character plots the murder of his wife. What ensues is no joke, but it still comes across with Hitchcock's facile touch, knowing all along it's entertainment, not shock, that we are after. And get, first rate.

reviews.review_title: Low-Key But Brilliantly Written And Directed Drawing Room Murder Thriller
reviews.content: Tony Wendice discovers that his wife Margot is having an affair with Mark, an American writer. Wendice blackmails an old college friend with a murky past into killing Margot while he and Mark are at a party, thereby giving him a perfect alibi. But of course there's no such thing as the perfect murder Hitchcock was a little disparaging of this movie, famously quipping that he "could have phoned it in". And yes, perhaps it is a bit stagy and talky, but that's doing it an injustice - it's a brilliant little thriller, with a terrific twist in the middle and a fantastic denouement involving a misplaced latchkey. It has a great villainous leading performance by Milland and a deliriously overenthusiastic score by Dimitri Tiomkin. Most importantly, Hitch fills it from start to finish with delicious visual flourishes; Tony spilling salt (foreshadowing his doom), the lovers' shadows parting on the door, Swan's shoes squeaking as he paces out the apartment, Tony's chilling goodnight kiss as he leaves Margot for what he thinks will be the last time, Swan's gleefully horrible demise, many others. The mechanics of the plot keep us gripped, but the director adds so much flavour with tightly composed shots, dramatic lighting and maximum suspense. I must confess I think this film has a liability however, and it's Kelly, in the first of her three roles for Hitchcock. She's a fair player but she has almost no range - check out the aftermath of the attack scene, where she simply is unable to play hysteria or look less than perfect to camera; all we see is her back and hear her voice over a phone. A great actress can play anything, and isn't concerned with how she looks, so Kelly doesn't qualify. This minor quibble aside however, this is a perfectly crafted little murder thriller that hasn't aged a day since it was shot. Based on a first-rate stage play by Frederic Knott - for another great film written by him, check out Wait Until Dark. Remade several times for TV and perhaps most interestingly as a feature in 1988 called A Perfect Murder, but as with so many movies the original is the best.

reviews.review_title: A visual and indirectly metalinguistic experiment in conducting a plot in a closed space, Dial M to Murder is the elegant representation of a crime planned in detail
reviews.content: Hitchcock was looking for the perfect crime. He imagined that a person gifted with coldness and intelligence would be able to organize and carry out a violent murder, without it being discovered. But he was overcome by slips and also by an audacious counterpoint, always present in his mystery plots. This clash between the criminal and an insistent inspector fueled many of his works, such as the exceptional Dial M for Murder, based on the Frederick Knott play, shown in 1952. Both the original text and this first adaptation present a plot of surprising twists, with a reduced cast and an almost unique setting, whose main merits are the convincing performances and the well-structured dialogues. On top of that, there's an extremely captivating villain, a case of infidelity, and a seemingly foiled crime. The three vertices that are the main (but not the only) attractions of the work and, also, some of the main aspects that are repeated in a peculiar way in the filmography of the master of suspense.Against his will and after firm insistence from Warner, Hitchcock agreed to direct Dial M for Murder in 3D, which brings us to the first major element of observation regarding the film, apart from its obviously theatrical construction: there is a wide effort by the director to put things in perspective, and even the most famous copy of the film, in two dimensions, demonstrates this.Frederick Knott, who in addition to the play, is also responsible for the excellent script, presents, in addition to striking and very well-crafted dialogues, disconcerting twists during the narrative. Shot most of the time in a single setting, the film never becomes tiring, thanks to the good editing by Rudi Fehr and the delicious dialogues of the script, which are even more attractive due to the good performance of the cast commanded by Hitchcock. In fact, the director has a large share of responsibility for the exciting pace of the feature, thanks to the firm direction of the narrative, which wastes no time and seeks to present the conflicts between the characters right away in its introduction, making the viewer aware of the problems between Tony and Margot and of her affair with Mark. In a few minutes, we already know about the extramarital affair, the intercepted love letters and the disappearance of the purse at a train station. In this same scene, Margot's red dress alludes to the violent future that awaited her (in addition to highlighting the character) and the luxurious house in which they live shows us the couple's good financial situation, revealing the good work of art direction by Margot. Edward Carrere. That is, in a single scene, Hitchcock presents us with vital elements for the progress of the plot and which will have a future reflection on the narrative.A clear example of the quality of the dialogues in "Dial M to Murder" is the long conversation between Tony and Swan (Anthony Dawson), which, at first, serves to introduce us to that new character and his past, and then show Tony's power of persuasion, who convinces his colleague to kill his wife through blackmail in a convincing way. Intelligent, Tony had studied Swan's life for a long time and knew that he could not refuse the proposal. The scene unfolds with incredible naturalness, thanks also to the excellent performance of Milland and Dawson, who move and speak as if they were in a real game of chess, where every word can mean an advantage for the "opponent". In this scene, it is also worth noting how the camera follows Tony's movements as he simulates how the murder will take place, preparing the viewer for that remarkable moment. After the dialogue, Swan finally takes the money - and Dimitri Tiomkin's dark trail emerges to reinforce that he's accepted the proposal.With this kind of dialogue loaded with cynical humor, but with so many frightening truths being told that it instantly manages to make us laugh with nerves for the mere suggestion of the violent act that the perfidious mind of the duo suggests. Mere words that manage to be as tense as the iconic murder scene itself, and you already know that this in a Hitchcock movie is already cathartic entertainment in itself and where the director has already broken all potential expectations of how this takes place and has its denouement. Orchestrating everything almost like a musical scene of absolute tension, from the brief 'rehearsal' scene of the act, where we see Wendice walking around the apartment and teaching step by step what Lesgate should do on the night of the murder, with Hitchcock leaving the camera almost like a penetration, capturing everything from above and following the movement of the characters with simple movements from one side to the other. And when the act finally takes place, the spectator is already almost taking off from the seat of tension, not knowing how the violent spectacle of aggression will end or who will emerge "victorious" from the agonizing strangulation.Like any good play, the film cleverly manages to split in half between two long acts with an intermission in between. With the first half having been devoted to a play about a murder thriller that defies expectations, while it has reserved a beautiful investigative drama ala Agatha Christie reserved for the second half of what this story has to offer, while also being where the movie is. Decays in its few slips. Although the character of Inspector Hubbard (John Williams) who is basically playing the detective Poirot or Sherlock Holmes of the story, it gives the feeling that it drops a lot of parachute from the middle of the plot, which leaves the character of Mark Halliday, being the supposed author of serial killer novels, becoming almost a cynical anecdote of the director himself within the film, the supposed expert in murder and who soon becomes a laughingstock of both Tony and Hubbard."Dial M to Murder" also features small moments of pure tension, like when Margot looks for something in her bag and says "I'm looking for my... aspirin". The viewer thinks, for a few seconds, that she would discover that her key wasn't there. Also notice the slow conduction of the scene in which Tony waits for the police to arrive at the same time he "prepares" the crime scene, seeking to incriminate his wife. Once again, the master of suspense prolongs the tense moments to the fullest. This is the secret to the story's success. During the investigation of the astute Inspector Hubbard (John Williams), Tony plays the correct game, not making clear his real intention to frame his wife - and Ray Milland does well in this aspect, demonstrating confidence in his words. Notice how, whenever he can, he tries to be solicitous and concerned about defending Margot, when, in fact, we know what he really wants is to condemn her. Hitchcock makes the viewer know more than many characters in the scene, creating, as he himself stated, the real suspense atmosphere.Elsewhere, Hitchcock frames Margot, Mark, and Tony, who says goodbye to his wife while surreptitiously placing the key under the rug. Mark observes everything, but doesn't realize what is happening. At the farewell, Margot finds her husband's kiss strange, as if she sensed what was happening - and Grace Kelly accurately demonstrates this through her worried face. Moments before, the conversation about the perfect crime helps to create the ideal atmosphere for the moment of execution of the plan, in addition to being reflected in the last scene, when Tony remembers a phrase from Mark. And then, as planned, the men go to the party and she is left alone, at the mercy of the cruel fate engineered by her husband. The even darker track indicates the tragedy as Swan approaches the Wendice house and even Robert Burks' photography, which until then had lighter tones, carries on the shadows and creates a very dark look, which increases the distress and collaborates with the atmosphere of suspense.As usual, Hitchcock works his big scene in every detail, starting with the time difference between Swan's and Tony's clocks, perceived first by the spectator and only later by the characters. It's these small details that can disrupt the duo's entire planning and serve to increase the tension even more. In addition to the clock, Tony comes across a man on the phone, just as he is going to call his wife. And then the phone rings and its ringing seems to make the viewer's heart flutter. Hitchcock knew how to extract tension from simple things and, in this case, an ordinary object like the telephone seems capable of hypnotizing the audience and leaving it in shambles. When she finally picks up, we don't know where Swan is, who is revealed through a beautiful camera movement, rotating around the entire scene until showing us the killer at the agreed location, right behind Margot. But he can't strangle the poor victim (and his hesitant look, seconds before attacking her, indicates that Swan wasn't the cold and cruel killer Tony expected) and, after fighting for his life, Margot manages to grab a pair of scissors and hit her. Him, killing him immediately. "Dial M to Murder" she then takes a big turn. What would Tony do now? It is precisely his meticulous and orchestrated action that we will follow, during the tense investigation that, without having a single action scene (in addition to practically taking place in a single scenario), manages to leave the spectator glued to the chair the entire time.With a lot of creativity, a good cast and a wonderful script, Alfred Hitchcock made "Dial M to Murder" one of the great films of his glorious career. A visual and indirectly metalinguistic experiment in conducting a plot in a closed space, Dial M to Murder is the elegant representation of a crime planned in detail and finished with the same class with which it is thought.

reviews.review_title: Great, but Lacking the Excitement Present in Hitchcock's Best
reviews.content: Dial M for Murder is a simple and well-crafted crime thriller with above average acting and directing. This is Hitchcock doing what he did best, providing the audience with a tense 105 minute ride that does lack the excitement in some of Hitchcock's best movies but is still perfectly good entertainment. This is not a movie I would consider an all time great, but one that I had no qualms with and enjoyed.

reviews.review_title: One Of The Most Clever Detective Movie
reviews.content: "Another very excellent movie by the one and only Alfred Hitchcock, Hitchcock made this movie as detail as he can, i really enjoyed the whole scene, and what i really like in this movie is they solved the case piece by piece very clearly, nothing missing, and that was awesome, overall Dial M For Murder is probably one of the most clever detective movie i've ever watch, i highly recommended"

Another work that the master director taught us... The film, which mostly takes place in one place, is masterfully edited and keeps its mystery until the last moment, asking the questions you want to ask, in short, it is a masterpiece that makes you watch it. The only thing I get stuck with is that the inspector looking at the passbook did not compare the writings of the 2 threatening letters Tony wrote with Tony's other writings. Do you believe in the perfect murder? - On paper, yes. A forgotten key became the key to the murder....

While there is nothing oustanding, great, or groundbreaking in this film, Hitchcock still delivers an enjoyable mystery that relys heavily on its plot, and takes place in only one setting. The dialogue rolls by smoothly and there are a few nice twists that accommodate. Overall, Dial M For Murder is a solid viewing, but not up to Hitchcock's other work.

Greetings from Lithuania."Dial M for Murder" (1954) is a one pure film to enjoy. As you have writing this good, even if the story does look a bit silly at the end it doesn't hurt the overall experience - "Dial M for Murder" is an highly involving story excellently told.I loved acting by Ray Milland as Tony Wendice - this character he is a one charming bastard - am i the only one who kinda rooted for him? Others were pretty OK for this material and the time when movie was made - but Ray Milland's performance was kinda ahead of its time. Directing by the legendary Alfred Hitchcock was great - at running time 1 h 45 min this movie was perfectly paced and was highly involving all the way long.Overall, "Dial M for Murder" is a simple mystery / detective story excellently told. Its not much as mystery actually, as we witness the whole crime story from the beginning. And its been a long time since i wanted for a bad guy to succeed. All in all this is an excellent movie.

I don't get the Hitchcock negativity with this film! I suppose it arises because he made so many greats over decades.The film was originally shot using early 1950s 3D technology by Warner Bros. 3D in the sense of some strange camera angles and vivid colours of household objects rather than the action/comic book 3D movie you get nowadays. It's not really needed. I watched the film in good old 2D and don't feel I missed out on the (early example) technology. I suppose it's another string in director Alfred Hitchcock's repertoire. He was always at the forefront of film gimmicks or experiments be it the long takes/real time of Rope (1948) to even the miniatures in The Lady Vanishes (1938).The casting includes Ray Milland and Grace Kelly as a married couple, Tony and Margot Wendice with Margot hiding an affair from Tony that of course he knows about and is planning deadly vengeance. Milland reminded me very much of a Cary Grant character and indeed I believe Hitchcock originally wanted to cast Grant who was unsure of playing a 'baddie' as such.The other major role is Mark Halliday (Robert Cummings). An American crime author who had an affair with Margot 12 months prior.Tony hires someone to kill Margot but the murder goes wrong is all I will say about the plot.The ending and indeed the Inspector provides twists to a mystery that appears solved. John Williams plays the Inspector role very much like Alastair Sim in a British film I saw recently, An Inspector Calls (1954).The film was originally a stage production and you can see why with the film nearly all set in the London home of the Wendice's.A typical Hitchcock murder mystery that is worthy of a viewing.

If you are looking for a well-crafted thriller to enjoy, look no further than Alfred Hitchcock's 1954 masterpiece, Dial M for Murder. On the outside, nothing much seems to happen with the film, but once you see it, well you are in for a surprise. As Hitchcock films goes, this one is more off-beat. However, you can classify the film as one of best films of the legendary director's career.If you look at the film from the outside, you are wondering how on earth is this film even good. For starters, most of the film is located in a single apartment room save for exterior shots and a scene at a theater. You need a well-crafted screenplay for single-location movies to work. Also outside of one rather fantastic murder scene, most of the film is talk, talk, and more talk. But this film does work because everyone plays their cards right. The screenplay is well-crafted and despite all the talk, it creates an aura of tension and mystery which builds up over the course of the film, before we reach the shocking ending. The build-up is excellent and it is very much worth it when the end is revealed. I also like that despite the movie being located in one room 98% of the time, you never get that feel of unintentional claustrophobia. So thanks to the excellent screenplay by Frederick Knott and masterful direction by Alfred Hitchcock, you never really think about that one location.Now it's time to describe the plot of the movie, which takes place in London. The wealthy Margot Mary Wendice (Grace Kelly) had a brief love affair with an American author named Mark Halliday (Robert Cummings). Her husband, Tony (Ray Milland), a professional tennis player, was away from home at the time on a tour. However, he quits tennis because he wants to spend more time with Margot, and help a marriage that is crumbling apart. One day, Mark decides to visit the couple from America. During the affair, Mark had written letters to Margot. She insists she destroyed them all, but one letter was stolen. She claimed she was blackmailed, but she never really thought much about that letter. When Tony arrives home, he insists Mark and Margot go to the theater, and he will arrive shortly thereafter. However, he ends up calling an old colleague, Captain Lesgate (Anthony Dawson). Together, they plot the murder of his wife so he can gain her fortune. But complications arise in the form of failed opportunities, the police led by Chief Inspector Hubbard (John Williams), and Tony trying to constantly cover his footsteps so he will not be implicated in any wrongdoing.Here is a film that is a masterpiece when it comes to delivering acting skills. Ray Milland injects his character with an incredible amount of charm, and his character is often likable even if his motives are not. His simple charm was enough to win me and many, many people over, enough to believe how he would do nothing wrong. Grace Kelly is absolutely magnificent in her role as Margot. During the murder scene, her performance was enough for me to wish she was nominated for an Oscar, which sadly enough she wasn't. These were the two main attractions of the movies, but there was another great performance to point out. John Williams (no, not the legendary composer), has been a staple of Hitchcock movies, so it is no surprise for him to show up here. I really loved his finesse role as the police detective who figures out this case, piece-by-piece with a remarkable eye.Hitchcock is one of Hollywood's most famous auteurs. When one think of his works, usually The Birds, Vertigo, Rear Window, or, Psycho comes to mind. But never count out this underrated film. During the first phase of 3-D phase in the 40's and 50's, many films were subjected to 3D treatment. However the faze begin to die out in the mid 1950's, and this is the last film to use 3D during that phase. I did not have the opportunity to watch the movie in 3D, but it could have been cool. For those who watch Hitchcock films, you should be familiar with him appearing in his movies somehow, someway. In Dial M for Murder, you'll really have to search to find him and it's a genius move to see where you'll find him.Overall, Dial M for Murder is just pure, classic Hitchcock. It's one of his underrated films, but there is no denying it is a masterpiece. The premise is a simple one, but Hitchcock turned into a twisting tale that pierces the heart with a load of dread and thrills. It's a very captivating movie, not only from the direction, but also from charming performances from Milland and Kelly, whom characters are likable. The film is good at talking, but you should be good at watching. I highly recommend this fine thriller that has Hitchcock in top form.My Grade: A

An oldie but goodie. Grace Kelly, Ray Milland and Robert Cummings star in this love triangle. Based on a play, the film mostly takes part in a living room with Grace Kelly as a clueless wife of the gold digging Ray Milland, a former tennis star now just a man of leisure living off of his wife's money. Cummings falls for Kelly and her husband decides to murder his wife in order to collect her fortune. He meets an old college classmate and blackmails him to do away with Kelly. The best laid plans go awry and Hitchcock steers the viewer in several directions, as expected. The cast is terrific and the less said of the story the better. Just sit back and watch how a thriller should be done.
This is one of the best noir movies. Again, Hitchcock did a good job.

reviews.review_title: Way better than the cheesy title suggests.
reviews.content: Enclosed to just a couple of rooms pretty much but a vivid experience.Filed with rich color, deftly chosen, the script, with its tons of small but important details where things are deduced both rightfully and wrongfully is just an amazing feat of writing all visualized with panache.

This film tells the story of Tony and Margot Wendice. She's married, but ends up having an affair with Mark Halliday, an American writer of detective novels. Therefore, and to avoid giving up her fortune, Tom decides to murder her but his plan goes wrong and Margo kills, in self-defense, the man who would kill her. Tom, to avoid the risk of being discovered, quickly creates a plan to take his wife to be sentenced to death.Directed by the great Alfred Hitchcock (one of the most brilliant directors of all time), this film, like others he directed ("Rear Window," "Psycho", "The Rope" etc.), is based on a police investigation, and the dramatic tension of the plot resides in its development, putting the audience in expectation, waiting to see when the killer will be unmasked in their eagerness to try to save himself. That's a formula that Hitchcock used so often in his movies that it's difficult today to see this movie and don't feel that disappointment of those who expected something more, or something different. Nevertheless, this movie is good, is very well done and has a great cast (headed by Grace Kelly, Ray Milland and Robert Cummings, respectively in the role of Margot, Tony and Mark Halliday) toasting the audience with great interpretations. The technical aspects (photography, soundtrack etc.) also seems faultless."Dial M for Murder" is a film that already has a few years, and probably we've already seen it on the small screen. Despite this, and despite not being one of the best films of this director and being totally unable to cause us astonishment or surprise, it's a nice movie to see, or review.

"The best way to do it is with scissors." (Alfred Hitchock's 'humorous note...)Charles Ramirez Berg notably points out that "Alfred Hitchcock deftly blended sex, suspense and humor." Although there are plenty of other, more outstanding productions that prove the skill unquestionable, DIAL M FOR MURDER is no exception from the rule. This film, however, will leave you speechless because of three aspects: confined feeling, improbable MacGuffin and excellent trio of leading stars. Consequently, the movie appears to be skating on pretty thin ice likewise the leading character who too earnestly plans but too easily slips up...The setting of this movie is no great spectacular location, like it would be the case of NORTH BY NORTHWEST or VERTIGO; it does not reach a loud crescendo like in A MAN WHO KNEW TOO MUCH, it is no psychological drama in the mode of PSYCHO or SPELLBOUND nor does it reveal any Hitch's haunting effects like THE BIRDS or REBECCA. DIAL M FOR MURDER, the first movie made in 3D technology (paradoxically, released in the format after Hitchcock's death) with the screenplay by Frederick Knott, can boast of something on its own: striking use of colors, innovative experiments with visuals as well as almost claustrophobic settings that results in a rather confined feeling. The camera-work beautifully corresponds to the perceptions of viewers who are, in a way, involved in the world of the characters. Sometimes, the camera positions itself in such a way that even our perceptions resist the supreme spell of suspense. Consider the image from the top when the murder is being planned. We see the flat suddenly, in a different way, more from the watcher's point of view. For every little step is measured, every movement planned. Yes, we cannot escape being there, feeling the mood of the growing action and awe inspiring magnetism of single details.The movie's MacGuffin (famous Hitchcock's concept) revolves around the key that requires particular attention absorbing a viewer entirely. Here, as nowhere else, the director's precision and considerable commitment is remarkable. Mainstay thematic concerns, like suspense, wit, obsessive desires, neatly-planned murder are present here along with the director's cameo presence that does not make us wait forever. While tension grows, mistrust appears to place seeds of doubt about the motives. Objects like notes, a latchkey, gloves, watch and telephone create this tension remarkably. Unlike some other films, we know what happens, we seem to know the motives, nothing truly might appear as 'unpredictable' and yet, the viewer's attention is kept throughout in truly impressive tension. You cannot simply allow yourself for skipping even the slightest detail though you know who the villain is and you know that the villain is doomed to be punished (for unlike in real life, movies of the time had to punish the baddies). But this is achieved primarily thanks to wonderful performances.Although there are many supporting cast who do wonderful jobs and also contribute considerably to the magic of the entire movie, the trio of Grace Kelly, Robert Cunnings and Ray Milland is unforgettable. One of the three films that resulted from Grace Kelly/Hitchcock's great rapport sheds light on some new aspects of this beautiful, talented, highly sophisticated woman that embodied Hitchcock's ideal of beauty. She is captivating as Margot, a woman torn apart between two men, whose feelings are constantly changing, a woman whose relationship with her husband appears to be on pretty thin ice, whose illusion turns into disillusion and trust into mistrust. The entire emotional scheme of the movie is placed in her and delivered perfectly. Ray Milland is another milestone performance of a man who is exact, precise, stylish, decisive, extremely controlled and yet, not thoroughly. Something must break him at last...Robert Cunnings is a typical Hitchcock's positive character who is though very lucky to merely witness all that is going on.Among the supporting cast, particular attention should be paid to Anthony Dawson as Captain Lesgate, a reflective, rather sympathetic character subverted to a murderous scheme and punished most. John Wyman also does a fine job as police officer Hubbard. DIAL M FOR MURDER, though not one among Hitchcock's top movies, is a highly entertaining, extremely involving movie that I would recommend to everyone who is bored with fake development of schemes and silly climaxes that we encounter so often nowadays. Yes, authentic make-believe is something that makes this film so convincing, like Tony who makes everything look authentic since this border between reality and disguise might be placed on pretty thin ice. And...you will never forget these scissors... 9/10

reviews.review_title: There are holes in the keys
reviews.content: There are 315 reviews in IMDB today (May 18, 2019) so I don't think #316 is absolutely necessary. Nevertheless, let me add a few key points (pun intended).First, I decided to give ten stars because this really is a very entertaining flick. Is it a crime or thriller movie? Not really unless the viewer came directly from Mars/Venus.Second, a rich socialite lives in a tiny one-bedroom apartment? Yeah, right.Third, what kind of people don't have spare keys (aka latchkeys)? It appears that no one in England has any.Fourth, and most significantly, it looks like that in England every man keeps his bare keys in his (one and only) coat pocket. No keychain, no keyring, no nothin'. Gimme a break.Anyway, I had fun watching it yesterday in 2D. I saw it some years ago in 3D as well, but that was a torturous experience (because 3D is weird).In summary, I highly recommend "Dial M for Murder" to anyone who wants fun but if you want a genuine hair-raising experience then pick another Hitchcock movie.Sincerely, PaulN (the proud owner of roughly speaking a dozen spare keys to his house even if he is not a rich socialite or the husband thereof)
Such a great thriller movie, didn't expect much in the beginning but eventually alfred Hitchcock proved me wrong🖤

"Dial M for Murder" is Alfred Hitchcock's film about a man that organizes a "perfect murder" for his wife with an accomplice. An important distinction between this and other Hitchcock films is that mystery and suspense come not from attempting to ascertain what is happening, but rather if any of the characters can discover the details of a crime the audience has witnessed.Ray Milland is Tony Wendice, the man organizing the crime. Milland is well-suited to his role as a man calculating and resourceful. Grace Kelly, Robert Cummings and Anthony Dawson are solid in their roles as well. However, my favorite performance comes from John Williams as Inspector Hubbard. Williams skillfully presents a subtle characterization that gradually makes a transition from easily dismissed to commanding.Though I generally prefer films with mysteries to be solved to those where the crime is known to the audience but not the characters, this film's story is tense and engaging. There are a number of interesting twists in the story that keep it interesting. "Dial M for Murder" is an excellent mystery and suspense film from Hitchcock.

It is said that Hitchcock filmed the successful Frederick Knott play 'Dial M For Murder' as his creative juices were running dry and he needed a little inspiration. Hitch saw it as perfect vehicle for his favourite ice-cool blonde Grace Kelly. She stars as menaced wife Margot alongside the great Ray Milland, who creates one of Hitchcock's most memorable 'charming villains'.Ex-tennis pro Tony Wendice (Milland)needs money fast. His young, beautiful wife Margot is having an affair with another man, the writer Mark Halliday (an uninteresting Robert Cummings). Milland sees no problem with murdering his unfaithful wife- he's tired of her, and she has a very favourable bank balance. Of course, he doesn't want to do the dirty deed himself, so he blackmails an old college chum into committing the crime. He will enter the Wendice's apartment late at night, with Margot being home alone on account of Tony's perfectly-timed business-meeting, wait for Tony to call the residence and then sneak up behind an unknowing Margot and strangle her to death. It reads as the perfect murder- until things start to go terribly awry when Milland places the crucial phone call...Milland oozes charm as Hitchcock's villain. This is one of his best performances, coming close to the perfection of his portrayal of Don Birnam in 'The Lost Weekend'. He's so dry and funny and supremely confident in the success of his plan that we end up hoping he'll get away with it. One wonders why Grace Kelly tumbles for Robert Cummings. Boring, plain and unromantic as Halliday, he and Grace share zero chemistry . Is this is a deliberate ploy by Hitchcock? Grace herself is physically magnetic here. One of the most stunning women ever to 'grace' the silver screen, her timeless elegance is on full display. She equips herself much better here than in 'Rear Window' in terms of acting ability. Grace handles her role very well, she's never brilliant but she has some great moments, particularly in the notorious 'phone call' scene (watch what she does with those gleaming scissors). Hitch loved his icy blondes, and he also loved to place them in dangerous situations. Grace gets the worst of it here, but throughout her ordeal she looks beautiful, and her appearance in a sexy slip is given plenty of attention.There is plenty of great Hitch touches in 'Dial M'. It's essentially stage-bound, with most of the action taking place in the Wendice's apartment, and rather talky, yet Hitch works his magic and takes what could have been a standard crime pic into a very good suspense thriller. The latchkey McGuffin is a Hitchcock trademark, and I do love the opening sequence. Milland and Kelly (in white, with a strained look on her face)are seated opposite to each other at the breakfast table. Cut to a scene of the newly arrived Cummings, with Grace kissing him passionately (well, as passionate as these two mismatched screen lovers could get), a true scarlet woman in a bright red outfit and lipstick. Subtle brilliance by Hitchcock.Not up there with Hitch's masterpiece 'Vertigo' or 'Notorious', but a fine film otherwise.8/10.

Tony and Margot are an unhappily married couple. She is incredibly wealthy and he decides to have her murdered in order to inherit her fortune. His plan is sound but things go awry...Good murder-drama. Directed by Alfred Hitchcock, so not a surprise. Very clever, yet water-tight, plot. Hitchcock's direction is spot-on, as always. Builds the tension, and doesn't let the movie drift. Only negative is the acting of Ray Milland. His stiff-up-lipness is excruciatingly irritating. Was Cary Grant not available? I got the feeling Hitchcock wanted Cary Grant, couldn't get him, so got a lesser lookalike instead.

Amusing and Talky Stage Show Filmed in 3-D by Alfred Hitchcock. Maybe His most Overrated Film but that doesn't stop it from being Entertaining. Audiences who Like Hitch's "Rope" (1948), "Lifeboat" (1944), and "Rear Window" (1954) will no doubt Fall in Line among the Fans of this "Flat" Film that Takes Place entirely in a Flat, ironically, Artificially Enhanced to Provide Depth.Although coming at the End of the 3-D Experiment the Movie was Released in a Limited Run in that Format but Quickly became Only Available in the 2-D Experience Until 1980. The Dialog Flows Smoothly from Ray Milland and Grace Kelly but Robert Cummings is Unconvincing, Stiff, and almost Stutters at times and it is an Uncharacteristic Nervous Performance.The Rest of the Limited Cast does OK with Anthony Dawson as the Slimy Snakelike Contract Killer Remarkable. The Movie is very Well Done, but of course its Hitchcock and Compared to others in His Filmography it doesn't rise to the top, Although it is Immensely Popular. The Third Act is the Weakest when Things are Pieced Together in a Rush.Overall, certainly Worth a Watch for it is Hitchcock, and the Movie Stars Ray Milland and Grace Kelly. But Truth be Told, it isn't Much more than a Good Play Filmed by a Great Director and it's best left at that, for to Try and Stretch and say this is Great Hitchcock, well it just doesn't hold up.
